Context:
Program Name: Honours Bachelor of Food Studies
Code: H317
Credential: Honours Bachelor's Degree
Duration: 4 years (8 semesters)
Method of Study: Full-time
Starting Months: September
Domestic Tuition: $10,905.00 * † ‡
International Tuition: $24,339.00 ** † ‡
Program Location: St. James Campus
Experiential Learning: Includes a 14-week work-integrated learning opportunity between the second and third years, field trips, and two community-engaged learning placements.
Availability:
- Fall 2024: Open (Domestic & International)

Program Description:
- A four-year Honours Bachelor of Food Studies degree in Canada combining culinary arts and a comprehensive food studies curriculum.
- Eligible for a $1,000 entrance scholarship.
- Explore challenges facing the food system with a focus on justice and equity, sustainability and health while mastering various culinary techniques.

*  † Indicates footnotes or asterisks present in the original text but not provided here.
** ‡ Indicates that tuition fees may vary based on additional factors such as student status or program options.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Honours Bachelor of Food Studies Program H317 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The Honours Bachelor of Food Studies (H317) is a four-year program offered at George Brown College. The program focuses on justice and equity, sustainability, and health in the food industry. Graduates will be prepared for various food-related occupations such as culinary, education, tourism, recreation, health, food security, sustainability, economic development, agriculture, public policy, and research. Students will participate in a paid co-op placement and community-engaged learning opportunities.

The program includes a 14-week, 420-hour work-integrated learning opportunity between the second and third years, two 16-hour community-engaged learning placements, and field trips in the surrounding area. George Brown works with employers and industry partners to identify potential work experience opportunities, and students are encouraged to pursue independent industry work experience.

Upon completion of the program, graduates will have demonstrated their commitment to both culinary arts and understanding issues throughout the entire food system. They will have culinary skills in demand by employers across Canada and internationally and the training to build a successful career at home and around the world. Possible career pathways for graduates include various employment areas such as Food, with possible careers paths not limited to entry-level positions but also advanced roles based on focus and experience.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Honours Bachelor of Food Studies Program H317 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
Extracted Information:

Employment Areas: Food services, community and non-profit organizations, Government

Possible Career Paths in Food services: caterer, executive chef, chef, sous chef, chef de partie, food blogger, food journalist, food product developer, food writer, market researcher, menu designer, sustainability officer

Possible Career Paths in Community and non-profit organizations: campaign coordinator, community chef, community organizer, culinary consultant, farmers’ market coordinator, food justice educator, fundraiser, garden coordinator, grant writer, learning development specialist, outreach coordinator, policy analyst, program coordinator, researcher, urban agriculture coordinator

Possible Career Paths in Government: policy development officer, program coordinator/manager, project coordinator/manager, public health promotions, public health specialist, research analyst

Educational Pathways: Graduates of this program will be prepared to continue their studies post-degree in master's programs in environmental studies, food policy, justice studies, public health, gastronomy, education, community development, communication and media studies. Graduates may also be eligible for direct entry into the Culinary Arts – Italian, French Pastry, Food and Nutrition Management programs

Required Courses:
SEMESTER 1: Smart Serve (HOST 1068), Introduction to Food Studies I (HOSF 1304), Culinary Skills I (HOSF 1267), Gastronomic Theory I (HOSF 1269), Communicating About Food (HOSF 1305), Food and Beverage Cost Control (HOSF 1145), Sanitation (HOSF 1146), Emergency First Aid/Heartsaver CPR (weekend course)

SEMESTER 2: WHMIS (HOSF 1287), Introduction to Food Studies II (HOSF 1306), Butchery and Café Production (HOSF 1283), Culinary Skills II (HOSF 1293), Gastronomic Theory II (HOSF 1295), Food Literacy (HOSF 1302), Lower Liberal Studies Elective

SEMESTER 3: Food for Special Events (HOSF 2303), [HOSF 2307 not listed in the text]

Context:
Program Information:
- The program focuses on acquiring culinary skills, operational knowledge, and integrating a healthy, equitable, and sustainable food systems perspective into culinary theory and practice.
- Students will be able to construct arguments for debates within the food studies field, appraise research methodologies, and communicate effectively in various environments.
- Demonstrating curiosity, initiative, integrity, collaboration, and social responsibility are required.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition: $10,905 for Fall 2023 intake
- International Tuition: $24,339 for Fall 2023 intake
- Additional costs include small wares ($100–$300), books ($1,600), and co-op work term (not included in the fee).
- Fees are subject to change.

Financial Assistance:
- The program is approved for OSAP funding, provided the applicant meets eligibility criteria.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Honours Bachelor of Food Studies Program H317 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text mentions that this program is approved for OSAP funding and that it is an applied degree program. The name of the college is George Brown College. The admission requirements include having an Ontario Secondary School Diploma (OSSD) or equivalent with six grade 12 university (U) or university/college (M) courses, including grade 12 (U) English and an overall average of 65% in the six grade 12 (U) or (M) courses. Mature students may apply if they are 19 years of age or older with no OSSD, have grade 12 (U) English with a grade of 65% or higher, and have completed post-secondary courses in English. Students must meet the English language proficiency requirements. The program has been granted a consent by the Ministry of Colleges and Universities to offer this applied degree for a 7-year term starting December 21, 2020.

Context:
For domestic students, they should apply through Ontario Colages (no specific program mentioned). Domestic students can contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions web page for inquiries about admission requirements, deadlines, and the admissions process.

For international students, they should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System. International students can contact the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid web page for inquiries related to OSAP, bursaries, scholarships, and other financial matters. For general Chef School inquiries, they can contact CHCAStudentSupport@georgebrown.ca.

There are several programs offered by George Brown College: Honours Bachelor of Food Studies (H317), Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Culinary Management) (H315), Culinary Management – Nutrition (H119), and Culinary Management (H100). Interested individuals can contact international recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry, visiting the International Contact Us page for more information.

Campus tours and info sessions can be booked, and tailored resources can be signed up to make the application process easier. The contact details provided are: Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.
